articles.headline: Officers Battle Visa Hurdles for Iraq Aides
articles.snippet: Veterans have rallied to help Iraqi interpreters through the difficulty of obtaining visas to immigrate to the U.S.
articles.abstract: Veterans have rallied to help Iraqi interpreters through the difficulty of obtaining visas to immigrate to the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lt. Col. Michael Zacchea left Iraq in 2005, he was torn. His yearlong mission to train an Iraqi Army battalion had left him wounded and emotionally drained, and he was eager to go. But leaving Iraq also meant leaving Jack, his Iraqi interpreter, to face an insurgency that has made a point of brutalizing those who help the Americans.

articles.headline: Clinton Beats Obama Handily in West Virginia
articles.snippet: Race was an unusually salient factor in Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victory over Senator Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: Race was an unusually salient factor in Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victory over Senator Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton arranged to meet with uncommitted superdelegates on Wednesday following her lopsided win in the West Virginia primary, as her supporters argued that her appeal to some traditional Democratic voting blocks may change some opinions despite the continued long odds that she can secure her party’s nomination.

articles.headline: Fearing Red Herring in the Data
articles.snippet: What are we supposed to make of the latest batch of better-than-expected economic news?
articles.abstract: What are we supposed to make of the latest batch of better-than-expected economic news?
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a month ago, a recession looked inevitable. Job cuts were picking up speed, and stock prices were falling. The Federal Reserve was cutting its benchmark interest rate rapidly, in an effort to keep the downturn from snowballing. But the notion that the economy could avoid a recession altogether seemed fanciful.

articles.headline: Indians Find U.S. at Fault in Food Cost
articles.snippet: Instead of blaming India and others for the rise in food prices, Americans should rethink their energy policy — and stop eating so much, say a growing number of Indians.
articles.abstract: Instead of blaming India and others for the rise in food prices, Americans should rethink their energy policy — and stop eating so much, say a growing number of Indians.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  Instead of blaming India and other developing nations for the rise in food prices, Americans should rethink their energy policy  and go on a diet.

articles.headline: Discounters Fared Well in Quarter
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart Stores and the TJX Companies said that sales and profit surged during the first three months of the year as consumers flocked to their discounted merchandise.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart Stores and the TJX Companies said that sales and profit surged during the first three months of the year as consumers flocked to their discounted merchandise.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s bargain time in American retailing.

articles.headline: A Rescue in China, Uncensored
articles.snippet: The rescue effort playing on Chinese television is remarkable for a country that has a history of concealing the scope of natural calamities.
articles.abstract: The rescue effort playing on Chinese television is remarkable for a country that has a history of concealing the scope of natural calamities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Mothers wailing over the bodies of their children. Emergency workers scrambling across pancaked buildings. And a grim-faced political leader comforting the stricken and reassuring an anguished nation.

articles.headline: Icahn Is Said to Weigh a Proxy Fight at Yahoo
articles.snippet: Carl C. Icahn is considering a proxy fight for seats on Yahoo’s board in hopes of pushing the company to restart talks to sell itself to Microsoft.
articles.abstract: Carl C. Icahn is considering a proxy fight for seats on Yahoo’s board in hopes of pushing the company to restart talks to sell itself to Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Microsoft-Yahoo merger story may not be over yet.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: A City Cooler and Dimmer, and, Oh, Proving a Point
articles.snippet: An Alaska city has cut its electricity use by more than 30 percent in weeks, but not necessarily for the greater good.
articles.abstract: An Alaska city has cut its electricity use by more than 30 percent in weeks, but not necessarily for the greater good.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUNEAU, Alaska  Conservationists swoon at the possibility of it all. Here in Alaska, where melting arctic ice and eroding coastlines have made global warming an urgent threat, this little city has cut its electricity use by more than 30 percent in a matter of weeks, instantly establishing itself as a role model for how to go green, and fast.

articles.headline: Congress Votes to Stop Stockpiling Oil
articles.snippet: Both the House and Senate voted by wide margins to halt shipments to the strategic petroleum reserve as long as prices remain high.
articles.abstract: Both the House and Senate voted by wide margins to halt shipments to the strategic petroleum reserve as long as prices remain high.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Groping for a quick response to rising gas prices, Congress voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to order the Bush administration to stop depositing oil in a national reserve even though lawmakers predicted the impact for consumers would be modest at best.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Oil Refiners See Profits Sink as Consumption Falls
articles.snippet: Oil refiners have not been able to to raise gasoline prices enough to pass along the full increases in oil, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Oil refiners have not been able to to raise gasoline prices enough to pass along the full increases in oil, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: While drivers are facing sticker shock at the pump these days, here is a bigger shock: high prices are putting a strain on oil refiners.

articles.headline: Quake Toll Rises; China Struggles to Reach Victims
articles.snippet: Rescue workers struggled to reach the tens of thousands of people who remained buried in the aftermath of the earthquake, as the death toll climbed above 13,000.
articles.abstract: Rescue workers struggled to reach the tens of thousands of people who remained buried in the aftermath of the earthquake, as the death toll climbed above 13,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: YONG’AN, China  The battle for survival here is as stark as anywhere in the earthquake zone.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Jake Hooker
